    texture_1: original=0x13fe0e188, current=0x13fe0e188 ‚úì

    texture_1 via old pointer: id=2, width=64, height=64
    texture_2 via old pointer: id=3, width=64, height=64

=== Demonstration Complete ===

The dangling pointer problem occurs because:
1. std::unordered_map may reallocate its internal storage
2. When this happens, all elements move to new memory locations
3. Previously returned pointers become invalid (dangling)
4. Accessing these pointers leads to undefined behavior

  tex_0: old=0x14100a428, new=0x14100a428 ‚úì
  tex_1: old=0x141011e28, new=0x141011e28 ‚úì
  tex_2: old=0x141012428, new=0x141012428 ‚úì

‚úì All pointers remained valid (implementation dependent)

Demonstrating the real danger:
Even if pointers didn't change this time, they CAN change.
The C++ standard does NOT guarantee pointer stability for std::unordered_map!
Iterators and references to elements are invalidated by rehashing.


=== Worst Case Scenario ===
Important texture at: 0x14100a428
Initial id: 1

Simulating production scenario...

After many insertions:
Original pointer: 0x14100a428
Current pointer: 0x14100a428

‚úì Pointer remained stable (but this is NOT guaranteed!)


Conclusion:
- std::unordered_map does NOT guarantee pointer stability
- Rehashing can invalidate ALL pointers to elements
- This is a critical bug waiting to happen in production
- Solution: Use std::unique_ptr or std::shared_ptr to ensure stability

=== Real World Scenario ===
Game started with critical textures:
  UI texture at: 0x130004080
  Font texture at: 0x130004080

Simulating gameplay with dynamic content...

After level 5:
  UI pointer still at: 0x130004080 ‚úì
  Font pointer still at: 0x130004080 ‚úì

Final check after all levels:
  UI texture: ‚úì Still valid
  Font texture: ‚úì Still valid


=== Summary ===
The current ResourceManager implementation has a CRITICAL bug:
- Pointers returned by loadTexture() and getTexture() can become invalid
- This happens when std::unordered_map rehashes (unpredictable)
- Game code storing these pointers will crash or corrupt memory
- The fix: Change storage to std::unique_ptr<Texture2D>
